The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mubarakâs ruling party, ''Baltageya''{{clarify|date=February 2011}} ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{Cite news|author=David KirkpAtrick|coauthors=Kareem Fahim|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian police sued for boy's death|publisher=BBC News|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're afraid of our own government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two witnesses affirm Alexandria victim beaten by police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=The Wall Street Journal |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally{{when|date=February 2011}} in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
+
The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mubarakâs ruling party, ''Baltageya''<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash"/> ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{Cite news|author=David KirkpAtrick|coauthors=Kareem Fahim|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian police sued for boy's death|publisher=BBC News|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're afraid of our own government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two witnesses affirm Alexandria victim beaten by police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=The Wall Street Journal |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in 2010 in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
